title: 253; Southern and Dixon

Some authors think that all legions, including the new Diocletianic ones, were 6,000 strong, which would strain manpower resources considerably; others suggest that although the new legions were 6,000 strong initially, they were reduced by Diocletian’s successors; see Jones 1964, 56; 68; yet others follow Mommsen 1889, 229; 254, who thought that the old legions remained at 6,000 but the new legions of the late third century were only 1,000 strong; see also Seston
Some of the legions may have been split up into detachments of 1,000 men and stationed in different forts

note: documents Persian attacks on Syria; Millar 1993, 141–147 describes the Roman–Persian wars to the reign of Philip.

The Diocletianic frontier, the Strata Diocletiana, was studied by van Berchem 1952. There are many Tetrarchic milestones along the route, and most of the forts along the stretches of the frontier that have been studied can be dated epigraphically to Diocletian or the Tetrarchy: Isaac 1992, 164; but see also Kennedy and Riley 1990, 70; 140 who point out that rebuilding at some of the forts on the eastern frontier makes it difficult to pinpoint their foundation dates
